addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

24 Junij
1594.
M
r
Bodley to my L:

page.lettertext:
fol.269r
May it please yo
r
good L. having nothing to
negotiat till I heare from yo
r
L. w
ch
I have not
done as yet, sins I came out of
England,
I am
humbly to beseeche yo
w
, if yo
w
thinke it so meete,
to lette me knowe assoone as may be, to w
at
effect I
shall addresse my further dealing w
t
e states.
They have taken suche order for supplie of
e garrisons,
as it is not to be doubted, but
at
e Enemies forces
being p
nt
ly dispersed, they are very well provided:
and yet their meaning is further, as occasions shall
require, to see them fournished as fully, as they have
bin at any time. I have also earnestly solici-
ted, to knowe an answear about
e shipping, whiche
e
Provinces
will send to
e enterprise of
Brittaine:
wherein I doe perceave by privat communicati
o
w
t
some of their Deputies,
at they have full co
m
ission
sent unto them, to take w
at
order they thinke meete.
But forasmuche as I my self am utterly ignorant,
bothe of
e number of shippes
at her
Ma
tie
will arme,
and of
e time
at is assigned for their putting to
sea, and of other besides very necessary pointes to be
knowen to them heere, before they can resolve, I am
forced to forbeare from dealing further w
t
them,
till her Hig
es
final pleasure be notified unto me.
From
e Campe before
Groeninghen
we are
thus advertised: That
e 13 day of this moneth the
bourghers made offer to capitulat w
t
Co. Maurice
,
requesting him to send his Deputies unto them: w
ch
he
promised to doe, so that they would send him hostages,
till
e Deputies returned. Wherunto when they
had yelded
e Co. sent his trompette, to conduct
e
hostages unto him. But while
e trompette was
w
t
in,
e souldiers of
Verdugo,
w
ch
lay entrenched in
the suburbes, and were, as is thought, 700 in number,
fol.269v
by
e practise of Jesuites, and w
t
e assistance of certaine
mariners, and suche others of
e towne, as disliked to ca-
pitulat, had a gate sette open to them, by w
ch
they entred
unwares to
e contrarie faction, put many to
e sword,
at were in consultation, advanced their enseignes about
the walles of
e towne, and committed besides divers
insolent actes. This was done
e 15 of this p
nt
, but
was unknowen to o
r
armie, till a bourgher
at escaped
and lept over
e walles, came to tell it Co. Maurice.
Wherupon
e next day after, he sent them a drumme
to require his trompette, and to knowe their resolution.
In
e time of their parley, it was accorded on bothe
sides,
at the great artillerie should not play, w
ch
was
a singular furtherance to
e finishing of o
r
workes,
having perced by
at meanes into 4 several places of
their dicke, w
ch
nowe they labor to fille up. The
17 day at night
e trompette being returned, Co.
Maurice was certified,
at
e bourghers had prevailed
against
e souldiers of Verdugo, and had driven them
againe into their trenches in
e suburbes, w
ch
is called
there
e
Schuytendiep
. And p
nt
ly upon it they renu-
ed their former suite by a letter to
e Co. requesting
him againe to capitulat w
t
them: wherunto he con-
descended, but refusing to be bounde as he had bin before,
not to use his great artillerie: w
ch
he perceaved by
some prisoners, did more terrifie
e bourghers, with
their firie bullettes, then any other force, or practise
of
e armie. They required in like maner, that
although they should conferre, and agree upon conditions,
they might yet be permitted to take 14 daies respitte,
to see w
at
succo
r
would come to them. W
ch
they seemed
to demaund, because Co. Maurice once before had made
them suche an offer. Howbei t by his l
re
of
e 19 he
replied unto them,
at thinges were nowe in an other
fol.270r
state, and sith
at before they rejected his offer, he
would not graunt so muche againe, but in
e worde
of a Prince he would assure them,
at there was no
succo
r
towardes, using speeches of persuasion to drawe
them to compounde w
t
out further delay. Howe this
l
re
is accepted we doe not understand: but every man
supposeth, and their maner of proceeding doth insinuat
no lesse, but
at they purpose to surrender.
Having had
e sight of an Abstract of
e
Empero
rs
pro-
position in
e diet of
Ratisbone,
I thought
at if yo
r
L.
had not seene it before, I should not doe amisse to impart
it unto yo
w
: for w
ch
I send it heere inclosed.
And so I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage. June 24
1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
